title: nwfscSurvey
text: nwfscSurvey package written scientists Northwest Fisheries Science Center (NWFSC) explore process survey composition data use groundfish stockassessments. package can used NWFSC West Coast Groundfish Bottom Trawl (WCGBT) survey, NWFSC slope survey, Alaska Fisheries Science Center (AFSC) slope survey, AFSC Triennial survey. package includes functions query NWFSC data warehouse, visualize, process data use groundfish assessments.

title: nwfscSurvey
text: nwfscSurvey can used : Pull survey catch, haul, biological data NWFSC data warehouse. Calculate design based indices based upon pre-specified stratification. Create length- age-composition data expanded design-based indices formated use Stock Synthesis. Create unexpanded conditional age--length composition data use Stock Synthesis. Create plots visualize data: design-based index plots, bubble plots length age data, observeed sex ratio, distributions across depth latitude.

title: nwfscSurvey
text: list functions packages can viewed :
code: ls("package:nwfscSurvey")

title: nwfscSurvey
text: Pull catch biological data:
code: catch = PullCatch.fn(Name = "Pacific ocean perch",                       SurveyName = "NWFSC.Combo")  bio   = PullBio.fn(Name = "Pacific ocean perch",                     SurveyName = "NWFSC.Combo")

title: nwfscSurvey
text: range functions create visualizations data examining catch rates latitude depth, lengths ages latitude depth, presence/absence tows, observed sex ratios.
code: plot_cpue(   dir = getwd(),    catch = catch)  plot_bio_patterns(   dir = getwd(),    bio = bio,    col_name = "Length_cm")  wh_plot_proportion(   data_catch = catch,   data_bio = bio )

title: nwfscSurvey
text: Define stratification depth latitude used calculate design-based index abundance: Calculate design based index abundance: Biomass.fn() returns list second element containing design-based index abundance. design based index calculated based defined stratas. function writes csv file inside dir input location “forSS” folder. function returns list second element containing design-based estimates year: Plot coastwide design-based index abundance: Plot coastwide design-based index abundance strata: dir equal NULL, “plot” folder created directory location png plot saved.
code: strata = CreateStrataDF.fn(   names = c("shallow_s", "mid_s", "deep_s", "shallow_n", "mid_n", "deep_n"),    depths.shallow = c( 55,   200, 300,    55, 200, 300),   depths.deep    = c(200,   300, 400,   200, 300, 400),   lats.south     = c( 32,    32,  32,    42,  42,  42),   lats.north     = c( 42,    42,  42,    49,  49,  49)) biomass = Biomass.fn(dir = getwd(),                       dat = catch,                        strat.df = strata) PlotBio.fn(   dir = getwd(),    dat = biomass) PlotBioStrata.fn(   dir = getwd(),    dat = biomass)

title: nwfscSurvey
text: GetN() calculates input sample size based Stewart & Hamel (2014) determined input sample size related species group (flatfish, shelf rockfish, slope rockfish, thornyhead, others, groups) number tows. function writes csv file “forSS” folder containing number tows observed fish year. SurveyLFs.fn() calculates formats length-composition data Stock Synthesis: call calculate length frequencies use Stock Synthesis write files inside “forSS” folder. example call assign unsexed fish sexed length comps produce csv files sexed unsexed fish. like assign unsexed fish sex based sex ratio user need specificy sex ratio value (sexRatioUnsexed) use fish specified size (maxSizeUnsexed) unsexed fish greater specified size assign based sex ratio observations. many inputs SurveyLFs.fn(), please look function inputs explore additional ways process data. plot length frequency data: new function visualize length frequency data also availble: dir equal NULL, “plot” folder created directory location png plot saved.
code: n <- GetN(dir = getwd(),           dat = bio,           type = "length",           species = "shelfrock") len_bins <- seq(10, 60, 2)  Length_Freq <- SurveyLFs.fn(dir = getwd(),                          datL =  bio,                          datTows = catch,                         strata.df = strata,                         lgthBins = len_bins) PlotFreqData.fn(dir = getwd(),                  dat = Length_Freq) plot_comps(data = Length_Freq)

title: nwfscSurvey
text: Calculate marginal age sample size: SurveyAFs.fn() calculates formats age-composition data Stock Synthesis: call calculate marginal age-composition data age data read using readInExcelAgeComps.fn() writes files inside “forSS” folder. plot age frequency data: dir NULL, “plot” folder created directory location png plot saved.
code: n <- getN(dir = getwd(),           dat = bio,          type = "age",           species = "shelfrock") age_bins <- 1:50  Ages <- SurveyAFs.fn(dir = getwd(),                       datA = bio,                      datTows = catch,                       strat.df = strata,                      ageBins = age_bins,                      nSamps = n) PlotFreqData.fn(   dir = getwd(),    dat = Ages)  plot_comps(   data = Ages)

Code within package allows pulling data NWFSC data warehouse, calculating design-based indices abundance, visualization data, processing length- age-composition data use West Coast groundfish stock assessment. code developed use scientists NWFSC intended work specific data products access using methods specific needs group.

what:
Calculates design based estimates from survey data for West Coast surveys.
The design based index is calculated based on the area of the strata and
the mean catch by strata.
See: Gunderson, D.R. and Sample, T.M. 1980. Distribution and abundance of rockfish off Washington,
Oregon, and California during 1977. Marine Fisheries Review: March - April. — Biomass.fn

title: Calculate effN input sample sizes — GetN.fn

NULL, default, files written disk. dat data.frame composition data. type string specifying whether "length" "age" used ensure sample size correct column create file name saved sheet. species string specifying species group interest, lead use correct species-specific value number unique samples per tow. See function call allowed values, default "". printfolder string used create name folder files saved, .e., file.path(dir, printfolder). output string, default NULL, returns vector samples sizes. title: Get Survey Abbreviation — GetSurveyAbb.fn
code: # Return a vector of agreed upon abbreviations for the # Triennial Survey and the West Coast Groundfish Bottom Trawl Survey. GetSurveyAbb.fn(c("Triennial", "Combo")) #> [1] "Triennial Survey" "NWFSC WCGBTS"     # \dontshow{ test <- GetSurveyAbb.fn(c("Triennial", "Combo")) testthat::expect_equal(c("Triennial Survey", "NWFSC WCGBTS"), test) test <- GetSurveyAbb.fn(c("Triennial", "bad")) testthat::expect_equal(c("Triennial Survey", ""), test) test <- GetSurveyAbb.fn(c("Triennial", "bad"), na.return = NA) testthat::expect_equal(c("Triennial Survey", NA), test) # }

title: Assign sex to unsexed fish based on fish with similar traits — SexRatio.fn
text: x data frame nested list depending sexRatioStage dictate function called inside code expands data SurveyLFs.fn() SurveyAFs.fn(). sexRatioStage integer specifying stage expansion sex ratio applied. default value values 1L`` 2L` appropriate. sexRatioUnsexed numerical value within [0.0, 1.0] used sex ratio measured individuals less maxSizeUnsexed. NA_real_, sex ratio stage-1 expansion conducted. maxSizeUnsexed numerical value specifying right side following bin [0, maxSizeUnsexed], fish measured bin assigned sex based sexRatioUnsexed. Fish measurement larger value assigned sex based calculated sex ratio data. bins vector measurement bins used bin measurement interest. Passing bins argument ensures appropriate "like" fish found, .e., bin missing data fish measured fell bin code aware bin missing. TODO: argument avoided bins factors levels documented. verbose logical specifies want print messages warnings console. default TRUE.

title: Assign sex to unsexed fish based on fish with similar traits — SexRatio.fn
text: sex ratio calculated number females divided sum number females males. , value reported actually proportion females. SexRatio.fn() different behavior depending expansion performed, controlled using sexRatioStage argument. expansion factors returned data frame unaltered unsexed fish. TODO: Decide previous method intended expansion factors changed unsexed fish zero? Also, stage-2 expansion alter number unsexed fish stage-1 . TODO: Think function alters expansion sample sizes just report sex ratio stage used expansion functions . TODO: Change message stage-2 expansion better reflect code TODO: align stage-1 stage-2 expansion details written similar fashion. Stage-1 expansion: Sex ratio observations within tow/measurement bin combination applied unsexed fish within tow/measurement bin; Sex ratio observations within measurement bin across years applied unsexed fish within measurement bin sex ratio information available tow level; Sex ratio nearby measurement bins across years applied unsexed fish within measurement bin zero sexed fish. , nearby bins classified one measurement unit smaller larger current bin. Stage-2 expansion: Sex ratio sexed fish within measurement bin calculated every strata/year combination; Missing sex ratios measurement bin filled based sex ratio measured fish within bin across years strata; Still missing sex ratios measurement bin based sex ratio sexed fish near (.e., plus minus one) measurement bins away across years strata.

what:
Calculates proportion of age at length and reformats into SS format
Uses raw numbers at length, assuming that is a random sample conditioned on length and sex.
To use expanded numbers (up to strata areas), set raw=F
Only sex codes 1 and 2 and puts males and females on separate lines because the age@L is conditioned on sex (a sample of females of length 25cm, for example)
Gender=1: females only. Male values ignored
Gender=2: males only. Female values ignored.
lgthBins is either the interval between length bins or the actual length bins
note that 0 and Inf are tacked on the ends to account for lengths and ages outside the interval. You may want to add these in to first and last bin.
I assume all fish are sexed for age data, thus do not apply sex ratios for unsexed fish — SurveyAgeAtLen.fn

text: survey character entry one following options specifies survey pull data . input options : Triennial, AFSC.Slope, NWFSC.Combo, NWFSC.Slope, NWFSC.Shelf, NWFSC.Hypoxia, NWFSC.Santa.Barb.Basin, NWFSC.Shelf.Rockfish (NWFSC.Hook.Line working), NWFSC.Video. National Marine Fishery Service Alaska Fisheries Science Center (AFSC) Triennial survey conducted 1977 - 2004 occurring every 3rd year. initial year, 1977, survey traditionally used calculating AFSC Slope Survey (AFSC.Slope) along west coast U.S. began 1984 occurred annually 1988–2001, exception 1994 1998, surveys conducted. Prior 1997, limited portion coast covered year. U.S. West Coast groundfish stock assessments use four years consistent complete survey coverage (1997, 1999-2001). Northwest Fisheries Science Center (NWFSC) Slope survey (NWFSC.Slope) conducted 1998 - 2001. NWFSC West Coast Groundfish Bottom Trawl survey (NWFSC.Combo) conducted annualy starting 2003 (excluding 2020) samples U.S. west coast shelf slope 55 - 1,280 meters. Data can pulled one survey time, though working allowing vector survey names. Currently, NWFSC.Shelf.Rockfish NWFSC.Hook.Line supported. default NULL placeholder must replaced entry.

title: Code sexes into standardized strings — codify_sex
text: Information sexes can stored several forms. codify_sex() works standardize possible input values sex one three character values, .e., F, M, U. , codify_sex_SS3() runs codify_sex() input standardizes F M 3 values 0 match grouping sexed unsexed fish Stock Synthesis.

code: codify_sex(x)  codify_sex_SS3(x)

title: Code sexes into standardized strings — codify_sex
text: x vector values used store sex information. Can combination integers, single characters, NA values.

title: Code sexes into standardized strings — codify_sex
text: vector F, M, U values length x vector 0L 3L codify_sex() codify_sex_SS3(), respectively.

title: Code sexes into standardized strings — codify_sex
text: Pattern matching used via grepl() facilitate matching standard potentially erroneous matches. example, code can accommodate number white space characters text string via "^\\s*. Additionally, first letter character string importance code strictly looking versions female, male, unsexed, ignoring case. NA values coded U unsexed. manual produced Washington Department Fish Wildlife, https://wdfw.wa.gov/sites/default/files/publications/01754/wdfw01754.pdf, provides following information regarding various sampling programs codify sex. Alaska Fisheries Science Center Slope Survey stored sexes uses integers, .e., male (1), female (2), unsexed (3). Washington followed format Alaska Fisheries Science Center Slope Survey. Oregon California also use 1 males 2 females; 9 used unknown sex.

title: Code sexes into standardized strings — codify_sex
text: message printed screen values map F, M, U. example, happy entry x, summary  number times happy seen x printed screen via message happy coded U returned value still viable user made aware something potentially wrong x. See examples.

title: Code sexes into standardized strings — codify_sex
text: Kelli F. Johnson

title: Code sexes into standardized strings — codify_sex
code: # All values are successfully coded codify_sex(c("U", "F", "M", 1, 2)) #> [1] "U" "F" "M" "M" "F" # Some values are not initially successfully coded and # warning messages are printed to the screen prior to # changing the uncoded values to "U" codify_sex(c("U", "F", "M", "both", 1, 2, NA)) #> The following unmatched values were found n times in `codify_sex()`: #> 'both' (n = 1) #> 'NA' (n = 1) #> [1] "U" "F" "M" "U" "M" "F" "U" codify_sex(c("both", rep(5, 10), "both", 1, 2, NA)) #> The following unmatched values were found n times in `codify_sex()`: #> '5' (n = 10) #> 'both' (n = 2) #> 'NA' (n = 1) #>  [1] "U" "U" "U" "U" "U" "U" "U" "U" "U" "U" "U" "U" "M" "F" "U"  # Change codified sex from letters to integers for Stock Synthesis codify_sex_SS3(c("M", "U", "K")) #> The following unmatched values were found n times in `codify_sex()`: #> 'K' (n = 1) #> [1] 3 0 0

title: Estimate von Bertanlaffy growth parameters from lengths and ages — fit_vbgrowth
code: fit_vbgrowth(   Par,   Ages,   Lengths,   par_logspace = TRUE,   ReturnType = c("NLL", "Pred"),   sdFactor = 1 )

title: Estimate von Bertanlaffy growth parameters from lengths and ages — fit_vbgrowth
text: Par list von Bertanlaffy growth parameters log space ordered follows: K, Linf, L0, CV0, CV1. Names assigned provided. Ages vector ages years. Values NA accepted. Lengths vector Lengths cm. Lengths can NULL ReturnType == "Pred" predicting using ages, lengths just needed estimation purpopses. NULL, ensure one length measurement every age measurement. Values NA accepted. par_logspace TRUE/FALSE Indicates values "Par" logspace need converted back normal spaces. ReturnType single character value "NLL" default, leads negative log-likelihood value returned. "Pred", three values returned combination length age, low, prediction, high based input parameters standard deviation factor, .e., sdFactor. sdFactor number standard deviations include low high calculations. default 1.0.

title: Estimate von Bertanlaffy growth parameters from lengths and ages — fit_vbgrowth
text: Depending ReturnType, either negative log likelihood returned based fits data matrix three columns low, predicted, high values combination length age. Distance low high predicted value depends sdFactor, allowing confidence intervals based normal theory theories created.

title: Estimate von Bertanlaffy growth parameters from lengths and ages — fit_vbgrowth
code: if (FALSE) { bio_dat <- data.frame(Age = rep(0:30, each = 20),   Length_cm = rnorm(n = 31 * 20, mean = 50, sd = 5)) pars_in <- lapply(FUN = log, X = list(   "K" = 0.13,   "Linf" = 55,   "L0" = 5,   "CV0" = 0.1,   "CV1" = 0.1)) solve <- optim(fn = estgrowth.vb, par = unlist(pars_in), hessian = FALSE,   Ages = bio_dat[, "Age"],   Lengths = bio_dat[, "Length_cm"]) predictions <- estgrowth.vb(Par = solve$par, ReturnType = "Pred",   sdFactor = 1,   Ages = bio_dat[, "Age"],   Lengths = bio_dat[, "Length_cm"]) plot(bio_dat$Age, predictions[, "Lhat_pred"],   xlab = "Age (years)", ylab = "Predicted length (cm)") exp(solve$par) }

title: Plot proportions of factor levels (y axis) by bins (x axis) — plot_proportion
code: # Add presence/absence factor to data  temp <- catch_nwfsc_combo %>%    dplyr::mutate(new = factor(      cpue_kg_km2 <= 0,      levels = c(FALSE, TRUE),      labels = c("Present", "Absent")    ))   # Plot depth bins (50 m) by presence/absence with default colors  plot_proportion(    data = temp,    column_factor = new,    column_bin = Depth_m,    width = 50,    boundary = 0  )  # Plot latitude bins (1 decimal degree) by presence/absence with custom # colors plot_proportion(   data = temp,   column_factor = new,   column_bin = Latitude_dd,   width = 1,   boundary = 0 ) +   ggplot2::scale_fill_manual(values = c(     "darkorchid3",     grDevices::gray(0.7)   )) #> Scale for fill is already present. #> Adding another scale for fill, which will replace the existing scale.  # Plot depth bins (25 m) by sex (F, M, U) plot_proportion(   data = bio_nwfsc_combo %>%     dplyr::mutate(Sex = codify_sex(Sex)),   column_factor = Sex,   column_bin = Depth_m,   width = 25,   boundary = 0 ) #> The following unmatched values were found n times in `codify_sex()`: #> 'NA' (n = 1)  # Change to equal sized bars plot_proportion(   data = bio_nwfsc_combo %>%     dplyr::mutate(Sex = codify_sex(Sex)),   column_factor = Sex,   column_bin = Depth_m,   width = 25,   boundary = 0,   bar_width = "equal" ) #> The following unmatched values were found n times in `codify_sex()`: #> 'NA' (n = 1)

title:
Pull biological data (age, length, weight) from the NWFSC data warehouse
The website is: https://www.webapps.nwfsc.noaa.gov/data
This function can be used to pull a single species or all observed species
In order to pull all species leave common_name or sci_name as NULL — pull_bio
text: common_name character entry desired common name species want pull data data warehouse. Use vector names want information one species desired species included database using one name, e.g., vermilion rockfish (see example ). Use sci_name argument know latin name. sci_name character entry desired scientific name species want pull data data warehouse. Use vector names want information one species desired species included database using one name, e.g., vermilion rockfish (see example ). Use common_name argument know common name. years integer vector length two range years pull data . survey character entry one following options specifies survey pull data . input options : Triennial, AFSC.Slope, NWFSC.Combo, NWFSC.Slope, NWFSC.Shelf, NWFSC.Hypoxia, NWFSC.Santa.Barb.Basin, NWFSC.Shelf.Rockfish (NWFSC.Hook.Line working), NWFSC.Video. National Marine Fishery Service Alaska Fisheries Science Center (AFSC) Triennial survey conducted 1977 - 2004 occurring every 3rd year. initial year, 1977, survey traditionally used calculating AFSC Slope Survey (AFSC.Slope) along west coast U.S. began 1984 occurred annually 1988–2001, exception 1994 1998, surveys conducted. Prior 1997, limited portion coast covered year. U.S. West Coast groundfish stock assessments use four years consistent complete survey coverage (1997, 1999-2001). Northwest Fisheries Science Center (NWFSC) Slope survey (NWFSC.Slope) conducted 1998 - 2001. NWFSC West Coast Groundfish Bottom Trawl survey (NWFSC.Combo) conducted annualy starting 2003 (excluding 2020) samples U.S. west coast shelf slope 55 - 1,280 meters. Data can pulled one survey time, though working allowing vector survey names. Currently, NWFSC.Shelf.Rockfish NWFSC.Hook.Line supported. default NULL placeholder must replaced entry. dir directory ouptut saved. directory file saved. dir = NULL output saved. convert TRUE/FALSE convert column names first letter uppercase aligns expected names data processing functions. verbose logical specifies want print messages warnings console. default TRUE.

what:
Pull biological sample information from the NWFSC data warehouse for biological
collections taken at sea. Generally these are samples that require lab processing.
Generally, these types of biological sample are maturity, stomach, fin clips, and
tissue samples. This function returns collection information for these samples
include the sample numbers which allows the lab analysis to be linked back to
the sampled fish.
The website is: https://www.webapps.nwfsc.noaa.gov/data. — pull_biological_samples
